Clearfield
Pittsburgh

FIRST DAY: Saturday, August 6 - From Lancaster, Pa. to Delmarva Peninsula, to Kiptopeke Beach, ferry across Chesapeake Bay to Norfolk, Va., to within a few miles of Elizabeth City, N. C. 6:15 A. M. to 5:15 P. M. 310 miles.

Dover, the capital of Delaware, was laid out by order of William Penn in 1683. The State House (shown right), begun in 1787, is the second in age in the country still in use, Maryland's alone being older. Delaware prides herself on being the first state to ratify the U. S. Constitution in 1787.
Photographs by 35 mm Contax IIa camera, with f1.5 lens. Film is Kodak Super XXX, Tri-X-, and Adox KB-21.

blocks.text: In Salisbury, Md., we call upon the Weaver and Maggs families. The children clamber aboard the boat Paul Weaver has sailed to Cape Cod and Miami, Fla..

We enter Virginia's Eastern Shore where today is found the purest strain of Anglo-Saxon blood in America, dating from 1607. The land is extremely flat with the Ocean and Bay not far away on either side.
An early stop the first day at Bob's Motel just north of Elizabeth City, N. C. ($10.30 with air conditioning and television.)

blocks.text: SECOND DAY: Sunday, August 7 - Elizabeth City to Kitty Hawk and Roanoke Island, to New Bern, to near Wilmington, N. C. 7:35 A. M. to 7:45 P. M. 343 miles .- total 653 miles.
Headed for the Outer Banks, the ribbons of sand off the North Carolina coast, where pirates plundered in days of old and where some 2,200 craft have met disaster in the past 400 years.
The three-mile Wright Memorial Bridge over Currituck Sound, last connecting link with the mainland.
At Kitty Hawk, first opportunity to get the feel of the Ocean. We expected to find barren dunes, but the water front is built solid with cottages, motels and hotels.

blocks.text: The Wright Brothers National Memorial at Kill Devil Hill, erected in honor of Wilbur and Orville Wright, who here on December 17, 1903 made the first flights ever made by man in a powered machine heavier than air. The memorial shaft is a triangular pylon of gray granite, 60 feet high, with an observation platform at the top.
The climb to the top of the hill, with the added climb to the top of the pylon, makes us all perspire freely on this extremely hot day.
The granite boulder in the far distance designates the take-off spot of the first successful flight. Viewed from the top of the pylon.

blocks.text: On Roanoke Island, a visit to reconstructed Fort Raleigh where the first English settlement in America was attempted in 1585. Here was born on August 18, 1587, Virginia Dare, first white child of English parents born in America. All attempts at colonization failed and the colony disappeared without trace. Paul Green's symphonic drama, "The Lost Colony", is presented at the Waterside Theater.

blocks.text: Waiting for the free ferry to take us across Croatan Sound which separates Roanoke Island and the mainland. After a wait of 20 minutes we are the second car which can not be accommodated, so we have another wait of 45 minutes. We decide to have lunch.
Gulls follow the ferry as we cross Croatan Sound.

We make fast time over the lowlands and drive to within 7 miles of Wilmington,
N. C. for the night. (Motell 2 rms $9.78) NNN.C.
The girls enjoy the spray which whips over the low-lying ferry.

blocks.text: WHITE ONLY

As we have lunch at this wayside restau...
rant a hummingbird poises over flowers outside the window.
Kitty stands before a familiar sign in the South.
North of Charleston the negroes have erected dozens of stands along the road to bid tourists buy their woven baskets. We pay $1 each for three of them.
The city of Charleston is built on the tip of a peninsula formed by the Cooper and the Ashley rivers. To enter the city we cross the two mile, two span Cooper River Bridge which is toll free.

blocks.text: Charleston has a charm all her own. Many fine old homes still stand. The architecture is Georgian, with strong French and Dutch influences. Unique is the elongated Georgian style with gable end toward the street and the side away from the street lined with full length piazzas, which face walled gardens to be entered through elaborate wrought iron gates.

After crossing the Ashley River Bridge we head south from Charleston on the highway bordered by huge trees which are heavy hung with Spanish moss. The children claim it gives them a "spooky" sensation.

blocks.text: It's 115 miles from Savannah to the Fla. line. We run into extensive road work. As we proceed, more and more roadside stands try to lure the tourist with curio shows.
Savannah, Ga. in the distance.. A new road and a new high bridge over the Savannah River bypass all but a corner of the city.
We arrive at dusk and immediately secure a motel right on the Florida line ($8.50). Kathy and Louise display their elation at being in Florida at last.
After the children have gone to bed, Gordon gets a picture of them asleep on their first night in Florida...and then snaps one of himself looking into the mirror (both by available light).

Savannah
TALLAHASSEE
Pelicans heading up the coast frequently fly low over the Ocean the easier to spot unsuspecting fish.

"A rare old bird"
old bird is the pelican,
His beak holds more than his bellican.
He can take in his beak
Enough food for a week.

blocks.text: Many sightseers view the ancient city in motorized trains, shown left passing through the old city gates, or by horse and carriage, shown right in front of the oldest house, said to date from the late 16th century.
The oldest wooden schoolhouse, erected in the mid 1700's, with hand-hewn clapboards.
Prince Murat House (about 1790) where the nephew of Napoleon lived in the 1820's.

blocks.text:
The Castillo de San Marcos,
successfully besieged by
the British in 1702, 1728,
and 1740, the last time for
37 days by Gen. Oglethorpe
from Georgia. This fort is
within the city limits of
St. Augustine.

The Castillo, remarkably well preserved, is a fine example of Spanish Renaissance fortification. Complete with moat and drawbridge, it is built of 16 foot-thick walls of coquina blocks quarried across the Bay.

blocks.text: From St. Augustine, we once again head down the coast securing frequent glimpses of the Ocean. The children avail themselves of every opportunity to wade in the warm water.

Daytona Beach is called the "most famous beach in the world", and the "speed capital of the world". Certainly there are few beaches as hardpacked and pebble free as Daytona's. Gordon and Kitty would not recognize it as the same place they last saw in 1937, so great is its growth in motels and cottages.

Daytona Beach is called the "most famous beach in the world", and the "speed capital of the world". Certainly there are few beaches as hardpacked and pebble free as Daytona's. Gordon and Kitty would not recognize it as the same place they last saw in 1937, so great is its growth in motels and cottages.

blocks.text: Palm Beach, one of the most fashionable Winter resorts in the United States, is almost deserted in the month of August. Most of the fabulous water front estates are boarded up, some of them perhaps permanently thanks to Uncle Sam's tax bite.

blocks.text: SIXTH AND SEVENTH DAYS: Thursday, August 11 and Friday, August 12 - At Ocean Grande Hotel in Miami Beach, with two visits to Miami. 85 miles - total 1,595 miles.

The row of hundreds of waterfront hotels in Miami Beach is duplicated no where else on earth. Fabulous is the only word to describe the scene...and in winter the rates are fantastic. But this is August, and we seek out the modest Ocean Grande Hotel (above) at 37th St. where we obtain two air conditioned rooms, with four single beds and two roll-aways, two baths, private ocean front bathing and a private swimming pool at the unbelievable price of $12 per night.
Miami Beach in August is far busier than this mid-day street photograph indicates. In the distance is the new Hotel Fontainebleau built at a cost of fifteen million dollars.
(ABOVE) The beach in front of our hotel; (left) the private pool the girls prefer to the ocean.
On Thursday we are visited by Bill and Alice Neuman, former Lancastrians now residing in Hollywood, Fla. On Friday we visit Frank Gabor's office in Miami.

EIGHTH DAY: Saturday, August 13 - Leave Miami Beach in late morning, to Miami, to Coral Gables to visit Frank Gabor's home. south across the Florida Keys to Key West. 11:00 A. M. to 7:00 P. M. 177 miles – total 1,722 miles.

After leaving Coral Gables at 1:00 P. M., we head south through Homestead where we encountered a brief, but intense, tropical storm so characteristic of Florida. The sun is soon out again as we drive through the wasteland of southern Florida, described as a continent emerging from the sea.

A pleasant surprise - the Overseas Highway across the Keys is now toll free. This Highway consisting of a number of bridges connecting the Keys, one of which is 7 miles long, is a beautiful drive of 130 miles between the Atlantic and the Bay of Florida. The road has been built on the original bridges for the railroad Flagler

blocks.text: NINTH DAY: Sunday, August 14 - Key West return across the Keys to Homestead, to Tamiami Trail across Everglades, to Naples, to Fort Myers. 10:30 A. M. to 6:20 P. M. 300 miles – total 2,072 miles.
Key West, southmost city in the United States, is 157 miles from Miami, and only 90 miles from Cuba.
END OF U.S. ROUTE NO. 1 KEY WEST, FLA.
The end of the road (the Route # 1). We spend several hours touring the city before we decide we must retracce our way over the Keys to the Florida mainland.

blocks.text: The children insist on buying a variety of shells and aquatic forms on display at the Aquarium.

At the green turtle "crawles" where scores of turtles weighing up to 400–500 lbs. have been brought from the Cayman Islands off the coast of Nicaragua. Their meat is shipped to all parts of the country. Their breathing produces an eerie sound.
U.S. POST OFFICE KEY LARGO FLORIDA

On the return trip, almost back on the mainland, we stop at the post office at Key Largo to mail letters to friends and relatives at home. We pass a steady stream of cars bringing fisherman into the Keys.

blocks.text: The Everglades - timeless, mysterious, fascinating, a land of trackless sawgrass prairies where dwell the remnants of the Seminoles who refused to be moved to Oklahoma at the conclusion of the Seminole Wars, the most costly Indian War in our history. Today, these Seminoles live in palm-thatched huts, some of which can be seen along the Tamiami Trail where the Indians cater to tourists.

blocks.text: (Right) The recently opened Sunshine Skyway ($1.75), consisting of causeways and an enormous bridge, across the mouth of Tampa Bay provides a short cut for travelers heading north or south and eliminates much of the traffic congestion formerly met in this vacation region.
(Left) The children run rush for the car when the suspension bridge lowers faster than they had expected.
TARPON SPRINGS CURIO STORE
TARPON SPRINGS CURIO STORE

Tarpon Springs, home of the largest sponge fishing industry in the United States, where the boats are still manned by Greeks who came here years ago to dive for sponges as they did in their native land. The town has a natural, picturesque, unspoiled-by-tourists appearance.

In general, the resort region of the west coast of Florida centering around Tampa Bay is less commercialized, less flamboyant than the east coast. You get the impression people come here to rest and relax, while the east coast provides the visitor with everything new that glitters and offers artifice.

blocks.text: The gaily colored boats which comprise the Greek fishing fleet at Tarpon Springs.
Mile after mile after mile of this type of monotonous driving along the west coast north of Tampa Bay area. There are only a few far-spaced and sleepy-looking cross roads towns.
Across the Suwannee River which Stephen Foster never saw. Gordon has just unknowingly closed the car door on Nancy's thumb (all right again in two days).

blocks.text: FLORIDA REPTILE LAND

It's getting late,
but we take time out
to inspect this
Florida Rep-
tile Land... much
to the children's
enjoyment.

A bargain - all of us are accommodated at the Perry Motor Mooter Lodge for $7.2l; after arrangements have been made, we are directed to a truck stop restaurant where we have a very satisfactory, low cost meal.

blocks.text: Mile after mile after mile of pecan groves.

Stone Mountain, 9 miles east of Atlanta, contains unfinished Confederate Memorial. It has become so dark picture above taken with 1.5 lens opening gives greater detail than was apparent time picture was taken.
The Capitol of Georgia in Atlanta, the capital city since 1867. Cindy is most anxious to see Atlanta, she having recently read 'Gone With The Wind'.

After Stone Mountain, always a disappointment because of its unfinished character,
we drive at night as far as Gainesville before findinga place to sleep. Every one
is tired after this long day.

blocks.text: TWELFTH DAY: Wednesday, August 17 - Gainesville, Ga. into N. C. at Highlands, to Great Smoky Mountains climbing to Newfound Gap and Clingmans Dome, east to within 10 miles of Asheville. 9:00 A. M. to 6:00 P. M. 241 miles - total 3,068 miles.

Mountains begin to appear on all sides. A long detour brings us to Highlands, N. C. Between here and Franklin, we pass beneath Bridal Veil Falls (right) and Dry Falls, which we discover are not as "dry" as the name suggests when we run under them to the far side. From Franklin, a good but multi-curved road leads across the mountains to Bryson City, almost in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

blocks.text: The town of Cherokee in the Indian Reser-vation where tourists flock to buy handi-crafts of Indian make. Here live the de-scendants of those Cherokee who refused to be driven westward to Oklahoma in 1839 when one fourth of those so died on the march.

The Great Smoky Mountains lie within easy reach of the great population centers of the eastern United States, yet until the early part of this century they were a vast unknown region. The mountain people lived as they did since Revolutionary War times. Today 50% of the forests are virgin timber. More species of trees are found than in all of Europe. The mountains are the highest east of the Rockies, 16 peaks being more than 6,000 feet. More than a million people now visit the Great Smoky National Park each year. Gordon well remembers his first trip across the Smokies in 1932 when the road from Gatlinburg, Tenn. to Newfound Gap was all dirt and so infrequently traveled grass grew in the center...a thrilling trip.

We climb the Great Smokies from Cherokee to Newfound Gap (5,045 ft.) which is the border between North Carolina and Tennessee. Tourists' cars from every state jam the highway, an unfortunate development since these mountains induce a desire to escape from crowded conditions.

blocks.text: The bears always cause unrestrained tourist excitementementt. Looking ahead and finding automobiles parked at odd angles, even blocking the highway, means bears are in evidence.
After leaving the Great Smoky Mountains National Park we head eastward across Soco Gap to within 10 miles of Asheville where we stop early to insure having a place to sleep. (Motels $8.24).

blocks.text: THIRTEENTH DAY: Thursday, August 18 - Asheville, N. C. to Blue Ridge Parkway, on Parkway to Roanoke, Va., to Shenandoah Valley road to just north of Natural Bridge. 8:30 A.M. to 8:30 P. M. 349 miles – total 3,417 miles.

The sun is shining brightly in Asheville when we begin the climb to the Blue Ridge Parkway. As we approach the top we drive into clouds and mist so that for the first twenty miles on the Parkway it is impossible to see more than two car lengths ahead. Only the white line in the center of the road enables us to proceed.

MT. MITCHELL STATE PARK
5 MILES →

blocks.text: The Blue Ridge Parkway literally rides the backbone of the Southern Highlands. The mountains are higher generally and more rugged, and more sparsely settled than the mountains further north which are traversed by the Skyline Drive.

blocks.text: We leave the Parkway nineteen miles south of Roanoke. Since the children report an "almost starved" condition, we stop for supper at the first roadside restaurant we come upon. It is not pretentious, but the food is good (and lots of it) at very modest cost. After supper we drive through Roanoke and head north on the Shenandoah Valley highway (R#11) as far as a point beyond the Natural Bridge where we secure accommodations as night closes in.

blocks.text: Cleveland
On way from Findlay to Columbus, Kitty and Gordon for the first time see the Warren G. Harding Memorial in Marion, which containsinthe tombs of the former presidentand MrMrs. Hardinging.

Delawaree, Ohio, 20 miles south of Mar-
ion, we discover is the birthplace of
President Rutherfordford B. Hayes.

The Andes, the Englands and Kitty and Gordon see Ohio State defeat Northwestern 49 -0 in a football game played before more than 82,200 people. A sharp wind has sprung up, in contrast with the mildness of the previous two days, giving Gordon and Kitty visions of a trip home in a snowstorm, which did not develop.

blocks.text: Painesville
HARRISBURG

The trip home in good weather on Sunday. (Left) Kitty and Kathy at a roadside park in Ohio. (Above) Automobile lights have been turned on in late evening as we average better than 60 miles per hr. on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
End - Trip to Ohio.

From among more than more than 100 aspirants, Cindy and Kathy are two of six selected to be junior high school cheerleaders. Our house goes through a long period of torment during the practice periods.

blocks.text:
December 5-12, 1955; Gordon, designated to head the Teacher Department of Educated carors Mutual Insurance Company, makes his first field trip through Pennsylvan- vania and Ohio. Accompanying him is Walter McClear, chief assistant in charge of special representatives.
The following agents are visited: Scheetz in Allentown; Simonson in Scranton; Person in Lewisburg; R. P. Miller in Titusville; England in Findlay, Ohio; England, Tromp and Well in Columbus to attend the Ohio Education Association meeting; Haney and E. C. Miller in Irwin, Pa.
Total trip - 1,332 miles - Chrysler.

blocks.text:
DRAKE WELL PARK
On this site" Col." Edwin Drake struck oil Aug. 27,
1859; the birth of the petroleum industry.
Administered by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.
The Drake Well Park, just outside Titusville, where Col. Edwin Drake struck oil in 1859 and founded the petroleum industry.

After dinner with Roy P. Miller in Titusville, we head westward into Ohio on the new Ohio Turnpike as far as Strongsville. Night in a motel. The next morning we again find the ground covered with snow.
Night overtakes us on the Ohio Turnpike. Lights from a gas station and restaurant gleam brilliantly in the darkness.
Outside the motel in Strongsville just as we are ready to depart. The snow dis- appears as we head west through Ohio.

blocks.text: Educators booth in Columbus, Ohio for the meeting of the Ohio Education Association. Bill Hell, Bob Tromp and George England show before the booth.
Gordon waits for delivery of his car in front of the Deshler Hilton Hotel.
The trip from Columbus to Lancaster made in one day, with a stop off in Irwin to see Charles Haney and Roy E. Miller.
End of trip - 1,332 miles.
